review_title: Great place to start off as fresh graduate / Great place to work if career is your top priority in life
pros:
Smart people , diverse culture , professional environment.
Most VPs (Gen X) are really top notch and deserve to learn from and look up to.
Generous meal and gym allowances .
Change is the only constant in Goldman.  Great place to work if you like curve balls being thrown at you daily.
Boot camp for GEN Y strawberries to mature into professionals (if you can survive for at least 3 years)
cons:
High turnover in some dumping ground departments [Especially in Operations]
1. You self resigned due to inability to cope.
2. You are laid off due to your incapability to perform to high expectations.

Lots of Japanese as they are known for their work grinding habits but micromanagement and inflexibility are also causes for concern.  Good luck if you have one that manages you.

Roles in SGP office are mostly back end  [ Operations & Finance ] and the more value adding MO to FO roles are predominantly based in HK and Tokyo offices.

Folks tend to focus too much on changing  for the sake of changing to justify their values and visibility till the change management create tons of downstream problems for others to pick up.

review_title: Great starting point, but need to value the high-performing worker better
pros: Very intelligent and driven coworkers, lots of personal growth opportunities within high-pressure environment context, and good analyst training program. All-around worker and management competence was very high.
cons: It was a newly established office (in TP location) cobbled together with fresh influx of newhires and global relocations. Very prone to multicultural misunderstandings, internal politics, and high-pressure to perform which lead a lot of people to 'show off' their work performance and taking credit of others which was demoralizing. Also operations is a lot of rout processing, not a lot of room for creativity, and the carrots the management dangled in front of analysts were mostly empty promises. That lead over 50% of analyst class easily to drop out within first year from boredom and lack of growth opportunities. Affiliation with the company name is seductive but be mindful of what job duties actually entail.

review_title: Great place to work at, but hours can get gruelling
pros:
The team I worked with is great - they were friendly and more than willing to impart their wealth of knowledge. Even senior management would often roll up their sleeves and get their hands dirty to resolve issues.

My team members had a deep passion for the market and were continually looking at all aspects of it. They persisted in looking at such a plethora of information just to expand their knowledge - nothing was considered an outlandish suggestion - we would look at all aspects of the fundamentals and positioning just to better understand the market dynamics.
cons:
The hours are rather gruelling, in my first year I worked around 110 hours a week - but I think that's something to be expected. You really have to put in the effort to maximise your development and trading abilities.

However, there have been departures with no replacements, and employees had to increasingly cover a wider range of responsibilities, which proved most taxing and I think brought about a lower productivity level overall due to general fatigue.

review_title: Looks good on the outside but not inside
pros:
Multicultural workplace - lots of emphasis on employee diversity, get to work with people from different cultures and nationalities 
High salary
Good brand name
cons:
NO work life balance work long hours 
Lots of emphasis on "visibility" - very individualistic environment, "over glorifying" one's performance and contributions
if you belong to the silent hardworking employee type- you will most probably be under appreciated and will never get a promotion
Lots of changes to lower management on a frequent basis- one can be working under many different managers (who come and go) within a relatively short period of time - which is bad because it will mean that whenever there is a change, the new VP is simply plugged into the team and does not know what you have contributed previously. At the end of the day, there isn't any real rapport or a solid team manager who has truly been there for the team all along to oversee or recognise individual employees' contributions and progression within the team over the years. Hence it can be frustrating for employees to constantly adapt to another new manager's style and team dynamics is always changing.

pros: The people in GS  that I have interacted with are extremely smart and for most parts, willing to help and share their expertise. Overall, the junior & VP population  is friendly and easy to get along with.
cons:
The culture might be overwhelming most new joiners / lateral hires, you are expected to manage expectations of multiple stakeholders both cross functionally and globally. Balancing work and personal life may be challenging  because of this. 

The "consensus driven culture" might sound great but with it, brings inefficiencies in day to day operations which is incredibly cumbersome and tiring. There are always "catch ups" to prepare for alignment meetings to prepare for the meetings and it really takes a village to get anything moving.  

There is always "discussions" by senior management on how to cut down these meetings but there have not been any actions/results. Again, multiple meetings with nothing to show for it.

review_title: Great place as your first job, but not a place to stay for long
pros: You get to work with the smartest in the street. People are generally helpful; they are willing to take time off their work to coach and guide you. You get pushed alot as if you are not the cream of the crop, you basically get eliminated in the rat race. Best place to learn how to manage stress as things move very fast here. If you can survive in GS, you can survive anywhere in the industry.
cons: People and things change too quickly, and it seems like the management has not been able to keep the good and smart people within the firm. Over the years, it felt like the culture of the firm has changed.

review_title: Not a good place for passionate software engineers, at least not Singapore office.
pros:
- Good office location, convenient transportation
- Good onboarding package, especially for undergraduates and foreigners (Oversea training, Reallocation etc.)
- Decent and smart juniors
- Some teams in New York are really good. They are driving the revolution and building awesome software (but not Singapore). 
- Free pluralsight/egghead.io/safarionline accounts. So you can access your favorite channel to learn latest technologies.
cons:
- It's not uncommon you realize people around in Technology are not technical. There are good and passionate engineers in the firm but I personally met more associates/managers who are quite weak in technology and super outdated.  If you are pursuing a technical career path to polish up your skills, I'd personally say it's not a right choice for you here.
- Your skills will be highly limited by all those internal platforms/tools/programming languages which are built internally. Most of them are wrappers on top of open-source projects and the internal tools/languages are lack of documents and support. It's really the most annoying part. You will become a task-executor but not an innovator. 
- You will get mad by support tasks. Those slack contractors won't help you much and eventually, chances are that you need deal with support tasks by yourself. 
- When you have lots of non-technical managers who talk a lot of sh*t during meetings/calls but doesn't know much about code, you feel tired and your fancy applications and projects won't make you stand out easily because they don't even understand what you have saved for them and what you are doing about.

review_title: Not work life balance but work life choices
pros: Get to learn from the best; on every aspect of business management irrespective of which division you are in. Opportunities are plenty if you reach out to others. Make time to interact and be fit mentally & physically. Tangible monetary rewards are good, so are intangibles like experience which benefits for longer term. Make the right choices,that's why you are here.
cons: You are working with the best so there will always be others better than you. Not a life long career for everyone. Can be tainted by monetary rewards and make bad choices to stay ahead. Affects family life and relationships. Due to multitasking, time is limited per task.

review_title: Work with really bright talent, but also work really hard
pros:
It is said that getting into the firm is harder than getting into the top universities in the world and it is fairly true that you work with a very hard quality workforce who wants to get things done. 

Open office and consultative culture means lots of phone calls and talking to ensure everyone buys into the idea.

Goes 110% into everything we do. It is tiring while at it, but you feel good when you are creating high quality outcomes
cons:
Demanding job scope, teams are often more lean than competitors meaning you do more. 

Clears out redundancy or low performers twice a year. Be on your toes

pros:
Great company in general, everything in terms of work visa, residence visa for spouse and children, especially HR related stuff is well organised and super professional.

Working wise - very strong team culture, constructive environment for junior to learn and grow

Technology stack wise - room to bring something new in, need bit of selling effort though
cons:
Promotion wise is not very transparent. It seemed to happen easier in London or Bangalore than Singapore. Especially disadvantage for non- English native, communication seems heavily weighted.

Compensation and perk were above market average but not very attractive

Dealing with some of the politics will waste your time, but this comes with the territory.

review_title: Good exit opportunities, but long hours and toxic environment
pros: GS definitely open doors. From day one, just being at GS, it gives you a certain pedigree, that friends at other investment banks won't have. Whether you are looking to get into PE, or other non-finance exit opportunities, GS alumni are generally pretty successful
cons: The downside is that the hours are long, and the workplace culture toxic. Expect to work past mid-night routinely. Even if you think that's not that bad and you can get used to it, trust me - it is. Doing this day after day, 6 days a week wares away at your sanity, mental, and physical health. Even if you are only planning on staying 2 years and leaving, trust me, this will be the longest 2 years you've ever had. If you had a chill undergrad (at a top tier institution, of course, and managed to maintain a strong GPA needed to get into GS in the first place), then maybe those 2 years will be more tolerable. For me, I didn't expect to go into IB in the beginning, and picked a pretty hard major. Burnout is very real

review_title: My journey of last 2 years in GS
pros: Someone who is not from circuital background but wants to enter big firms, GS is a good start. You work across with people through out the world, which increase your knowledge and social skills as in terms oh how to explain project to someone who is superficially involved in it. Decent pay
cons: No defined working hours. They dont help you improve your tech stack, as you keep on working on Slang. Good projects ( in terms of good knowledge of finance and maths ) comes rarely.

review_title: A great place to start your career
job_title: Software Engineering Analyst in London, England
pros: - The problems to solve can be very interesting - Most of the time you are being thrown into new technologies and out of your comfort zone, so end up learning quickly - Lots of socials and after work events to go to - Almost everyone you meet is approachable and you can have a nice chat with - It's finance so the pay is better than most places
cons: - Cog part of a bigger machine - the work you do doesn't always feel like it has an impact - Depending on which team you are in and the people you're with, there is a hierarchy and it can be hard to have your ideas implemented since they need to go through levels of discussion/approval - As secure as the job is, it can also be non-secure during the layoff period which can feel completely random - If you're not looking to climb the ladder and more interested in tech then I recommend leaving after a couple years.

pros: Experience gained for new Analyst
cons: No work-life balance. Expects employees to take on roles and responsibilities outside of their scope. Regularly asks employees to take on leadership roles without compensation or proper training, with a promise to consider promotion at their yearly review. This is usually entailing working a role for 6-9 months without the title or compensation. There were thousands of employees let go of this year that were not low performers, weeks before they were to receive their yearly bonus based off the previous years performance. They brought them into a scheduled meeting and let them go as a group. No clear expectation of severance or reason for being let go. Unacceptable. This year was worse than the other 4 years I have seen them dismiss employees at the start of the year as a way to clear house and cut costs as they can pay less for inexperienced employees rather than experienced ones.

review_title: Literally anywhere is better than working at Goldman
pros: Sometime you will have the occasional colleague that is a normal human but they are very much in the minority
cons: Toxic culture. Partners are incapable of managing people and won't hesitate to work people into the ground. They overstaff people to the point of burnout, there is literally an in-house psychiatrist to treat all the people they break. And when they make you redundant they don't pay your accrued holidays and if you're lucky enough to get the "generous" £30k severance you will spend most of it on therapy. I cannot stress this enough - DO NOT WORK FOR GOLDMAN SACHS. If you want to work for a bank go to JPM or Morgan Stanley instead

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: People were great, smart, and hardworking. Depending on your manager you can have a good work life balance. I did.
cons: Firm is really struggling to maintain talent/ compensation is one of the worst on the street. Role was migrated to Dallas and they couldn’t find any team to place me- wasted months twiddling my thumbs. As a high performer (promoted quickly, great reviews)- it was strange to be the only person moving my career forward. Ended up leaving as not to waste time.

pros: You will learn a lot on the job. No day is the same and you will be challenged, which is great if you're looking to advance your understandings of the markets and asset allocation.
cons: They have created a toxic culture that allows individuals in higher positions to treat subordinate staff poorly. You have a voice, use it if something isn't right.

review_title: You get out what you put in, but the Firm is only loyal to their shareholders
pros: Compensation is good for those who at in the top 10%. For everyone else the pay is mediocre. People are mostly smart and driven, and have a results driven mindset. The brand is strong and will carry a disproportionate weight on your CV. Owner mindset encouraged.
cons: Work-life balance is none existent if you want to get into the top 10%, like any other high flying job. Technology stack is antiquated and changing it is extremely slow/difficult (but a lot of progress has been made in recent years to start addressing this). Many senior people who don’t do any real work anymore and instead coast on the efforts of those beneath them (likely no different to any other company though). Extremely political and verging on toxic work culture.

review_title: Work hard, learn medium, earn mediocrely
job_title: Quantitative Analyst in New York, NY
pros: 1. Prestige within finance/quant 2. Learn how big companies work (very useful) 3. Learn financial jargon and concepts by osmosis (I wasn't very financially well-versed, feel pretty comfortable for my level after a few months)
cons: 1. In terms of hard math/cs it seems very hit or miss, with a lot more missing than hitting at the analyst level. If you are not a desk-quant (ie. work in controllers, corporate treasury, regulatory, etc.) you're probably doing very basic math, and very basic coding. 2. Very long hours spent on trivial items (checking out spreadsheets, translating spreadsheets to code, attending pointless meetings, debugging models that break because someone pressed the wrong button, etc.) 3. Coding languages/software are overwhelmingly old and proprietary. Quants generally code in Slang, a proprietary coding language with built-ins to handle financial objects, a graphical database, esoteric (and older) version of pandas, etc.. This must've all been very innovative 20 years ago, now it feels outdated, there is no convenient stack-overflow, and most of what you learn is esoteric and not transferrable to other jobs (or even other areas within the firm)

review_title: Good company, not always best long term view
job_title: AML Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Supportive & challenging culture, chance to work with global professionals, highly professional atmosphere, lots of opportunities to raise your hand & make a difference.
cons: Biggest thing is just the nature of working in a highly cyclical industry. Overhired during the pandemic, “party on” mentality, then had to do some serious cuts as the rate environment got tougher. Too many acquisitions over the last few years, when it was clear that we were in an extraordinary macro environment that wouldn’t have been able to last forever.

pros: Lots of really interesting work, and plenty of areas of the business to explore. The company really invests in its people, and it shows, from the workplace environment (free fresh fruit, ambient environment, and quiet rooms) to occupation health (separate business, where outcomes aren't up for debate with management), to culture development (frequent meetings with your managers, and a flattened structure, allowing you to get advise and support from anywhere)
cons: Compensation transparency is my biggest gripe

pros: The firm does a great job of hiring people from such different backgrounds and the average intelligence level throughout the floor is insanely high. You will learn so much in such a short amount of time and the exposure to so many different companies and seniority levels is amazing.
cons: The floor is insanely political and gossipy. The seniors don't care about your personal or intellectual health, they only care about execution and work product. It's like this in most investment banks, but within GS SF specifically, there have been an increasing number of medical cases going up due to lack of attention to personal care for the sake of the job. People throughout the floor are very ingenuine and when push comes to shove, they will always look out for their personal sake over the collective good of the team/floor. To summarize in two words, soul crushing.

pros:
- Great office
- Smart people
- Everyone’s approachable
cons:
Different teams have different cultures but Investment banking Ops has one of the worst and I’ll only stick to them as that’s where I worked
- Micromanagement - you’ll be constantly harassed and compared to your peers sometimes even openly.
- Zero flexibility - no work from home, you’ll be forced to stay in the office for at least 10 hours each day. People routinely work 12-14 hours per day and still berated on a frequent basis.
- No real perks either - no additional perks other than your salary (except office cabs which is a huge plus)
- Internal politics - very mentally exhausting internal politics inside the team. Work is secondary you’ve to be in the good books of the managers to get promoted.
- Everyone in the office will act like they’re in the best place to work in the world, only for them to do a 180 as soon as they step outside of the building. Most people hate working in this team and about 50% are looking for openings in other teams.

Promotions are given to friends and mutual friends . Sometimes some people get opportunities because they speak same language and the funniest part is these happen across all divisions. I knew someone ( friend of a manager ) who got promoted as manager because they mentored new joiners for a week whereas people who had actual team handling experience is still a specialist. Please if you think of upskilling yourself join Gs and learn stuff and leave. !! Be smart !!

review_title: Great internship and learning opportunity, but glad I didn't return
pros: The Goldman Sachs investment banking summer internship is a great way to learn about investment banking and their HR team does a great job of keeping the program organized and thoughtful. The internship involved both hands-on experience (on real deals, not just internship projects) as well as more "classroom" style learning. Pay was very good for an internship. Overall very grateful for the experience, but glad I didn't stay full time.
cons: During COVID, the remote internship experience was less exciting and cut short, although I can't blame any firm for the last minute adjustments required. The only downside is this is really a business with crazy hours, often working 80-90 hour weeks, with the expectation to work Sunday through Friday. (I asked about wanting to attend Church on Sunday and was advised against it - response was "Can't you find a service on Saturday?") Culture is highly dependent on group/team, I thought people seemed very nice during the internship, but have heard from friends that stayed that much of that was a facade.
